Under the background of the popularity of household gas-electric equipment, an interval optimization method considering the Integrated Demand Response (IDR) and tolerance degree is proposed to deal with the household load scheduling. The proposed method mainly tackles the dynamic switching of energy forms (natural gas and electricity) and uncertain variables in the system caused by household load and photovoltaic (PV). The thermostatically controllable loads contain gas-electric heater and air conditioning, and the interruptible loads contain gas-electric kitchen stove and clothes washer. An interval optimization model is formulated to optimize the operation cost and emissions of a household multi-energy system. The uncertain parameters are modeled as interval numbers, and the constraints are relaxed by tolerance degree. To solve the equation, the interval optimization model is transformed into a deterministic optimization model based on the interval order relation and interval possibility degree. Then, Genetic Algorithm is applied to solve the deterministic optimization model. Simulation results indicate that interval optimization is robust to the uncertainties and flexible to meet users’ demands. Both IDR and tolerance degree are able to optimize users’ energy cost, and the optimization results are accumulative. For a gas-electric equipment installed home, the proposed method can reduce expenditures by up to 23.4% compared with traditional method that do not consider IDR, tolerance degree and interval optimization. h equipment index buy buy electricity from the power grid sell sell electricity to the power grid Others N number of all the time steps of a day Δ t length of a time step(h) 1 Introduction 1.1 Motivation In order to reduce energy cost, an increasing number of households are equipping renewable energy systems such as PV and wind power systems. Many families also make comprehensive use of natural gas, electricity and renewable energy, etc. Electricity, natural gas, renewable energy and load equipment in households can be coupled through equipment and controlling systems. Such coupled system is named Household Multi-energy System (HMES) [1]. Moreover, a type of novel multi-energy equipment named gas-electric equipment has been installed in some homes, such as gas-electric heaters and gas-electric kitchen stove [2]. Such equipment is able to dynamically switch energy source between electricity and natural gas. The integration of gas-electric appliances promotes the implementation of IDR in HMES. The concept of IDR [3] is to coordinate different energy forms, such as natural gas, electricity, cold, heat on the demand side and load and energy conversion equipment, to achieve system optimization goals. Current researches on the operation optimization of HMES mainly focus on Demand Response (DR) programs of electric equipment [4] without considering dynamic energy switching between electricity and natural gas. In principle, the operation cost and emissions will be reduced due to enhancement of optimization depth if natural gas energy is included in optimization scope and household energy optimization is developed from electricity DR to gas-electricity IDR. Therefore, gas-electricity IDR is a considerable way in HMES optimization. Uncertainty is an important characteristic of HMES which posed challenges to scheduling optimization. The factors of uncertainty include at least three aspects as follows: (1) HMES contains uncertain energy such as wind power and PV. (2) Household loads are uncertain. There are many factors, such as climate, dynamic energy prices, incidental factors, consumer psychology and so on, that lead to different household energy consumption behavior. (3) Environmental variables e.g. ambient temperature and initial temperature of inlet water temperature are uncertain. Interval optimization [5] indicates some practical features in uncertain energy optimization, including: (1) Compared with robust optimization, the results of interval optimization are less conservative. (2) Interval optimization only needs to obtain the interval of uncertain parameters, while the probability distribution model is required in stochastic optimization [6]. (3) Compared with the method of ignoring system uncertainty, interval optimization is more robust. Therefore, interval optimization is adopted in this paper to solve the uncertainty problems in HMES. Tolerance degree is another important characteristic of HMES, and it can evaluate consumers’ attitude towards comfort violation [7]. For example, consumers require hot water temperature and room temperature to be maintained in a reasonable range, e.g. hot water temperature ranging from 56 °C to 68 °C and room temperature ranging from 23 °C to 28 °C [8]. Although, the occasional temperature fluctuation beyond this range is acceptable to consumers. This provides additional flexibility for load scheduling. In fact, heating accounts for about 40% of the household energy consumption [9]. Thus, tolerance degree is a potential factor in HMES optimization. Based on the above considerations, the theme of this paper is aimed at HMES with gas-electric equipment and its uncertainty. And considering IDR and tolerance degree, the interval optimization method is adopted to optimize the operation cost and emissions of harmful gas. 1.2 Related works At present, the researches on the operation optimization of household energy system are mostly focused on electricity DR. Four different types of resources are usually used in the framework of household DR programs [10]: utility power; local energy generation, usually based on renewable sources (mainly PV and wind power); electrical storage devices, mainly including electrical batteries and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles; and controllable demand appliances. The first and fourth types of resources are usually mandatory for these studies [11,12] while the second and third are selective. A large number of researchers have carried out relevant studies. For the system powered by utility power, Rasheed et al. [13] reduced the system energy cost through scheduling home energy load. Golmohamadi et al. [14] studied the coordinated optimization of energy load when the system contains utility power and PV. The program effectively reduced household energy expenditure. Jin et al. [15] proposed an operational strategy for systems containing utility power, PV, electrical battery and controllable demand appliances. The strategy cut down energy expenditure significantly. These studies have been proved effective. However, in above literatures, natural gas has not been included in the optimization scope. Therefore, the method is difficult to be directly applied to HMES with gas-electric equipment. HMES system management, which comprehensively considers combined heat and power (CHP) system and electricity, has also attracted some attention. In this type of system, the scheduling mechanism of electricity load inherits the electricity DR system, and CHP is adopted to schedule electricity and heat supply. Based on the concept of energy hub, Rastegar et al. [16] proposed an integrated energy management scheme including CHP, a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle, a heat storage unit, solar panels and generic household appliances, to optimize the system energy cost under different electricity pricing conditions. Anvari-Moghaddam et al. [17] studied a system optimization method that considered utility power, PV, heating/cooling system and energy storage to reduce the energy cost when multiple households share the same CHP system. Shirazi et al. [18] presented a smart home energy management model for joint scheduling of home appliances including two local energy generations, CHP, electrical and thermal storages. Simulation results demonstrated that the scheme can reduce the energy cost. These studies have shown that the operation optimization of household energy system has better economical performance when CHP is participated in. Regrettably, only few households have installed CHP, so plenty of good works have no chance achieve good work in reality [19]. CHP emphasizes converting natural gas into electricity and heat, while gas-electric equipment emphasizes the dynamic switching between electricity and natural gas. Hence, the scheduling mechanisms and models of CHP and gas-electric equipment differ, and the scheduling scheme cannot be universal. Thus, it is difficult to utilize those works on CHP and joint gas-electricity optimization to the optimization of HMES with gas-electric equipment. In household appliance market, gas-electric stoves and gas-electric heaters constantly emerge [2]. However, currently there lack researches that implement IDR in HMES with gas-electric equipment. Customers decide which energy source is consumed in particular time periods, but most users tend to use their appliances in a way to have the highest comfort level rather than considering the balance between comfort and cost. There are mainly four optimization approaches to deal with the uncertainty of household energy system: stochastic optimization [20], robust optimization [21], system optimization ignoring uncertainty [22] and interval optimization [23]. Stochastic optimization makes full use of the probability distribution of each uncertain factor. Wu et al. [20] proposed a stochastic optimization method for smart home energy management with the probability distribution of PV array. However, it is difficult for control solution providers to predict the probability distribution of PV in thousands of households [24]. Therefore, it is relatively difficult to apply stochastic optimization in HMES. In terms of robust optimization, considering the uncertainty of user behavior, Paridari et al. [21] proposed a robust optimization model to ensure the low-carbon economy of HES. In addition, a robust method was developed to tackle the uncertainty of PV output for load scheduling, and the midpoint of PV output interval was used to represent the actual predicted value [25]. However, it is generally accepted that robust optimization is of high security but conservative. Hence, robust optimization is difficult to fully optimize the operation cost and emissions of household energy system. A considerable part of studies ignored the uncertainty of the scheduling system and uncertain factors such as future PV output, wind power, load and temperature were regarded certain in system optimization [26]. This method is easy to be realized in engineering because of its small calculation amount. Due to the large deviation between the model and the reality, the robustness of scheduling results is not high, and may even affect system stability. In recent years, interval optimization [5] is becoming more and more popular in energy system optimization. The main reason is that interval optimization only needs to obtain the distribution range of uncertain parameters instead of its exact probability distribution. When utilized for optimizing the energy system with uncertainty, interval optimization shows the advantages of simple modeling, good robustness and acceptable calculation complexity [27]. Current researches mainly focus on distributed energy optimization [28] and the operation optimization of power system with wind power and PV [5,29]. These studies showed that interval optimization has good adaptability to complicated power systems and relatively simple distributed energy systems, which enables these systems to obtain the optimal or near-optimal solution within the interval of uncertain variables. Wang et al. [23] applied interval optimization in household load scheduling, in which ambient temperature and hot water demand are uncertain and are described as interval optimization model. Simulation results showed that interval optimization can adapt to different user demands flexibly and has strong robustness to uncertainty. However, interval optimization for IDR of HMES still remains a gap. Tolerance degree is also known as satisfaction degree. There are a number of studies on household energy system optimization that consider tolerance degree. Ogunjuyigbe et al. [30] proposed a demand side load management strategy that controlled loads within a residential building to achieve maximize user satisfaction by minimal expenditure. Wang et al. [23] also considered the importance of users’ tolerance degree to scheduling in household load DR by taking users’ tolerance degree as a constraint of the system. Nguyen et al. [31] studied a DR optimization strategy of thermal load integrated utility power and solar energy under real-time electricity pricing. It aimed at minimizing electricity cost as well as satisfying user’s thermal comfort. The strategy was able to maintain a flexible balance between users’ thermal tolerance degree and cost reduction. For HMES with utility power, CHP, renewable energy and controllable household devices, Anvari-Moghaddam et al. [17] proposed a scheduling method that considered users’ tolerance degree. And users’ tolerance degree was converted into the cost, constituting the optimization objective together with the energy expenditure. This was a cost-effective and comfort-aware HMES management solution. Above studies covered both pure electricity and CHP-integrated electricity system DR. However, when gas-electric equipment participates in IDR, how to combine tolerance degree and how the combination results will be still an open problem. 1.3 Paper contributions To address the above issues, an interval optimization strategy of HMES considering tolerance degree and IDR is proposed in this paper. The research subject is a system containing gas-electric equipment, conventional appliances and PV. The objective of load scheduling is to optimize the operation cost and the emissions cost of the system. The optimization method adopted is interval optimization considering tolerance degree and IDR. The contributions of this paper are as follows: • Gas-electric equipment is integrated into household energy management and the model of gas-electric equipment is formulated. • A novel IDR way in HMES is proposed that, gas-electric equipment is able to dynamically switch the energy sources between natural gas and electricity and regulate loads (including switching on and off), and other controllable loads regulate loads like conventional DR, while uncontrollable loads run as needed. • Interval optimization is applied to deal with the uncertainty in HMES with gas-electric equipment. The IDR model based on interval optimization is formulated, and the effectiveness of interval optimization for IDR is studied. • Users’ tolerance degree is considered in HMES with gas-electric equipment and modeled as constraints in the IDR optimization model of HMES, and the effectiveness of users’ tolerance degree for IDR is studied. 1.4 Paper organization The structure of this paper contains composition of smart HMES in Section 2, formulation of HMES load scheduling based on interval number in Section 3, solution of HMES load scheduling problem in Section 4, and cases study in Section 5. Finally, the conclusion is summarized in Section 6. 2 Composition of smart HMES A typical smart home integrates electricity, natural gas and PV energy as its energy sources. Electricity and natural gas can be obtained from utility systems and PV systems belong to households. Then, electricity generated by PV can be consumed by households or sold to the grid. The typical structure of smart HMES is shown in Fig. 1 . Water heater (WH) and kitchen stove (KS) are gas-electric equipment. The rest kinds of equipment are electrical, including television (TV), air conditioning (AC), clothes washer (CW), lighting and sensors. WH and KS can dynamically switch energy types, while they are not able to use both at the same time. Moreover, as the main part of household energy consumption, WH and AC occupy a high proportion of the residentials’ loads, that some households may reach 50% or even above [9,32]. In general, electrical storage device is a good optimized alternative that optimize the operation cost of household energy system. However, storage capacity optimization of gas-electric equipment installed in HMES is still an open problem. In order to avoid the theme of this paper being diluted by determining the storage capacity, electrical storage device is not integrated in this paper. Generally, as is known to us that smart home equipment can be divided into controllable and uncontrollable load [33]. Further subdividing, WH and AC can be considered as thermostatically controllable loads that can store energy. CW and KS are classified as interruptible loads. These loads are always discontinuous in the scheduling cycle. Energy consumption of uncontrollable loads, mainly including lighting, TV, can’t be reduced. And uncontrollable loads are unified as P mustrun . TV and lighting are assumed to be in a working or standby state in the scheduling cycle. Thereby, they won’t participate in the scheduling of HMES. WH, KS, CW and AC are controllable loads, so that they can be interrupted and delayed during scheduling cycle. 3 Formulation of HMES load scheduling based on interval number 3.1 Brief introduction of interval number The interval analysis was introduced by Moore to deal with the uncertainties [34]. According to interval mathematics, the interval number is defined as a pair of ordered real numbers: (1) A I = [ A - , A + ] = { x A - ⩽ x ⩽ A + , x ∈ R } In Eq. (1), A I , A - and A + represent the interval number, the interval lower limit and the interval upper limit respectively. The interval number degenerates to a real number when A - = A + . The interval can also be defined as (2) A I = A c , A w = { x A c - A w ⩽ x ⩽ A c + A w } A c and A w respectively indicate the midpoint and radius of the interval: (3) A c = A - + A + 2 , A w = A + - A - 2 Fig. 2 shows the geometric description of the interval. The possibility degree P ( a ⩽ B I ) is computed by [23] (4) P a ⩽ B I = 1 , a ⩽ B - B + - a B + - B - , B - < a ⩽ B + 0 , a > B + where a marks a real number and B I denotes an interval number. 3.2 Objective function of HMES load scheduling The objective function of HMES load scheduling is to minimize the sum of energy cost and emissions cost of HMES, which is expressed by (5) min X Z ( X ) = min X E + F + α ( C E e + C E g ) where Z ( X ) is the sum of energy cost and emissions cost, the energy cost is divided into the electricity cost E and the natural gas cost F , emissions cost is divided into the emissions cost of electricity C E e and the emissions cost of natural gas C E g , α is the weighted coefficient of the emissions cost. X is the decision variable tuple set: X = { X h , n , h = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 ; n = 1 , 2 , 3 … N } , where h is the index of equipment with energy types. h = 1, 2, 3, 4 respectively represents WH, AC, CW, KS while using electricity, and h = 5, 6 represents WH and KS while using natural gas. n is time step index, the upper limit N represents the total number of scheduling steps, X h , n is the working status of h at time step n , X h , n = 1 means the corresponding device is turned on, and X h , n = 0 means turned off. Since WH and KS consume only one type of energy at each time step, it’s obvious that: X 1 , n X 5 , n = 0 and X 4 , n X 6 , n = 0 . Due to the randomness and volatility of the external environment, PV systems have uncertainty in their output power [35]. The PV output can be modeled by interval number as (6) P PV , n I = [ P PV , n - , P PV , n + ] where P PV , n I is the PV output interval at time n. P PV , n - and P PV , n + are the lower and upper limits of PV power prediction respectively. The electricity cost can be described as (7) E = ∑ n = 1 N [ p n ( P mustrun , n - P PV , n I + ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) Δ t ] where p n is time-of-use electricity price at time step n , Δ t represents the length of each time step, P h is electric energy consumption of h in each step, P mustrun , n is must-run service at time step n, Generally, the buying and selling price of electricity differ for a user. Here illustrate the buying and selling price as follows: (8) p n = p buy , n if ( ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) + P mustrun , n - P PV , n I > 0 p sell , n if ( ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) + P mustrun , n - P PV , n I ⩽ 0 where p buy , n and p sell , n are the prices at which users buy and sell electricity respectively. Define that they are positive numbers. From Eqs. (7) and (8), it can be seen that the model of load scheduling is a piecewise function which is difficult to solve. Therefore, an absolute value function is introduced to eliminate the piecewise function as shown in Eq. (9). (9) E = Δ t 2 ∑ n = 1 N [ ( p b u y , n - p s e l l , n ) | P m u s t r u n , n - P P V , n I + ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h | + ( p b u y , n + p s e l l , n ) ( P m u s t r u n , n - P P V , n I + ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) ] The natural gas cost can be expressed as (10) F = ∑ n = 1 N q n ( ∑ h = 5 6 X h , n Q h ) Δ t where q n is the static gas price, Q h is the gas consumption of h in each step. It can be seen that the operation cost of HMES can be expressed as: (11) E + F = Δ t ∑ n = 1 N [ p n ( P m u s t r u n , n - P P V , n I + ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) + q n ∑ h = 5 6 X h , n Q h ] Since using PV produces no emissions, the emissions of electricity are expressed as follows [36]: (12) E eCO 2 = λ eCO 2 ∑ n = 1 N ( P mustrun , n - P PV , n I + ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) Δ t E eSO 2 = λ eSO 2 ∑ n = 1 N ( P mustrun , n - P PV , n I + ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) Δ t E eNO X = λ eNO X ∑ n = 1 N ( P mustrun , n - P PV , n I + ∑ h = 1 4 X h , n P h ) Δ t where λ eCO 2 , λ eSO 2 , λ eNO X are CO 2 , SO 2 , NO X emission coefficient of equipment using electricity. E eCO 2 , E eSO 2 , E eNO X are the emissions of CO 2 , SO 2 , NO X respectively, produced by electrical equipment. The main pollution emissions of natural gas are CO 2 and very low level of SO 2 and NO X . Then, the emissions of natural gas are expressed as follows [36]: (13) E gCO 2 = λ gCO 2 ∑ n = 1 N ∑ h = 5 6 X h , n Q h Δ t E gSO 2 = λ gSO 2 ∑ n = 1 N ∑ h = 5 6 X h , n Q h Δ t E gNO X = λ gNO X ∑ n = 1 N ∑ h = 5 6 X h , n Q h Δ t where λ gCO 2 , λ gSO 2 , λ gNO X are CO 2 , SO 2 , NO X emission coefficient of equipment using natural gas. E gCO 2 , E gSO 2 , E gNO X are the emissions of CO 2 , SO 2 , NO X respectively, produced by natural gas equipment. If users consider to pay the emissions cost, the emissions compensation coefficient must be introduced. Then, the emissions cost models of equipment are expressed as [37,38]: (14) C E e = u 1 E eCO 2 + u 2 E eSO 2 + u 3 E eNO X (15) C E g = u 1 E gCO 2 + u 2 E gSO 2 + u 3 E gNO X where u 1 , u 2 and u 3 are the emissions cost coefficient of CO 2 , SO 2 , NO X respectively. C E e is the emissions cost of electricity, and C E g is the emissions cost of natural gas. 3.3 Constraints of HEMS load scheduling 3.3.1 Constraints of WH In the operating model of WH, heat exchange between hot water and thermodynamics with working environment is under consideration. The thermal dynamic model of WH can be computed by differential equations [39]. When only taking the heat loss resulted from heat exchange, the thermodynamic model of WH is expressed as (16) θ W H , n + 1 = θ e n , n + ( X 1 , n + X 5 , n ) Q W H R W H - [ θ e n , n + ( X 1 , n + X 5 , n ) Q W H R W H - θ W H , n ] exp [ - ( t n + 1 - t n ) / ( R W H C W H ) ] where θ WH , n is hot water temperature at [ t n , t n + 1 ]. Q WH is capacity of WH, and it is the equivalent thermal power while WH uses gas. C WH and R WH are thermal capacitance and resistance of WH respectively. θ en , n is inlet water temperature at [ t n , t n + 1 ], and the default value is 8 °C. In this paper, like most WH, the tank of WH is uncontrollable. The water level of tank is determined by user behaviors. When considering the tank, the thermodynamic dynamic model of WH is updated as (17) θ WH , n + 1 = [ θ WH , cur ( M - d n ) + θ en , n d n ] / M where θ WH , cur is the θ WH , n + 1 calculated in Eq. (16), M is the total capacity of hot water tank, and d n is hot water demand at [ t n , t n + 1 ]. Taking the above two aspects into account synthetically, Eqs. (16) and (17) can be further combined as (18) θ W H , n + 1 = f 1 θ W H , n , t n , Q W H , C W H , R W H , d n , X h , n , θ e n , n For WH, because of the randomness of hot water demand, fluctuations in ambient temperature and heat loss in heat exchange, hot water temperature in the tank may be lower or higher than the set temperature in a long time, which is unacceptable for users. In order to ameliorate the above-mentioned biases resulted from uncertain factors, the interval number analysis is introduced. Then, the thermodynamic models of WH is converted into an interval number model. (19) θ WH , n + 1 I = f 1 ( θ WH , n I , t n , Q WH , C WH , R WH , d n I , X h , n , θ en , n ) where θ WH , n I is the interval of hot water temperature at [ t n , t n + 1 ], d n I is the interval of hot water demand at [ t n , t n + 1 ]. Most of users can tolerate that hot water temperature occasionally exceed the given range in a small scale. Combined with the possibility degree described by Eq. (4), the tolerance degree of hot water temperature can be expressed as (20) P θ WH , n I ⩾ θ WH ̲ ⩾ 1 - σ 1 P θ WH , n I ⩾ θ WH ‾ ⩽ σ 2 where σ 1 and σ 2 indicate users’ tolerance degree on the lower and the upper limits of hot water temperature. In fact, tolerance degrees can weigh users’ attitude to comfort violation. Further, the interval model with tolerance degree of WH is described as (21) θ WH , n + 1 I = f 1 θ WH , n I , t n , Q WH , C WH , R WH , d n I , X h , n , θ en , n P θ WH , n I ⩾ θ WH ̲ ⩾ 1 - σ 1 P θ WH , n I ⩾ θ WH ‾ ⩽ σ 2 Moreover, WH can only select one energy at time step n, thus forming a constraint as (22) X 1 , n X 5 , n = 0 3.3.2 Contraints of AC As for AC, it’s not disturbed by user behavior, so only needs to consider the heat loss by heat exchange between thermodynamics and air with working environment. The thermodynamic model of AC is computed by (23) θ AC , n + 1 = θ am , n + X 2 , n Q AC R AC - ( θ en , n + X 2 , n Q AC R AC - θ AC , n ) exp [ - ( t n + 1 - t n ) / ( R AC C AC ) ] where θ AC , n is the indoor temperature at [ t n , t n + 1 ], Q AC , C AC and R AC are capacity, thermal capacitance and resistance of AC respectively, θ am , n is ambient temperature at [ t n , t n + 1 ]. Eq. (23) can be further rewritten as (24) θ AC , n + 1 = f 2 ( θ AC , n , t n , Q AC , C AC , R AC , X 2 , n , θ am , n ) Due to environmental and weather factors, room temperature is uncertain. Similar to WH, the interval number analysis is also introduced to handle these uncertainties. The thermodynamic model of AC is converted into an interval number model. (25) θ AC , n + 1 I = f 2 ( θ AC , n I , t n , Q AC , C AC , R AC , X 2 , n , θ am , n I ) where θ AC , n I is the interval of room temperature at [ t n , t n + 1 ], θ am , n I is the interval of ambient temperature at [ t n , t n + 1 ]. During the scheduling cycle, the pause of CW may be feasible due to fluctuation of the electricity price. The start-up can be delayed within a certain time range. CW only needs to complete the setting task within the specified time range. The mathematical model of CW is described as (28) ∑ n = t CW , b t CW , e X 3 , n = L CW where t CW , b and t CW , e are the start time and deadline time of CW, L CW is the number of time steps in load scheduling range in total. 3.3.4 Constraints of KS As we know, the cooking time is divided into three parts: morning, noon and evening. At each run time range, the cooking process must be continuous. It can be seen that KS is also an interruptible load. Specifically, the mathematical model of KS is described as (29) ∑ n = t KS , b t KS , e ( X 4 , n + X 6 , n ) = L KS where t KS , b and t KS , e are the start time and deadline time of KS, L KS is the number of time steps in load scheduling range in total. Moreover, KS can only select one energy at time step n, thus forming a constraint as (30) X 4 , n X 6 , n = 0 3.4 Interval optimization model of HMES From Eq. (7), Eqs. (21) and (27), it can be seen that objective function Eq. (27)–(30). 4 Solution of HMES load scheduling problem 4.1 A method of transforming interval optimization into deterministic optimization The above HMES optimization model is a typical interval optimization, and the general expression formulation of this model is (32) min Y f ( Y , U ) Subject to (33) g i Y , U ⩾ b i I = b i - , b i + , i ∈ L , Y ∈ Ω n U ∈ U I = U - , U + , U i ∈ U i I = U i - , U i + , i ∈ Q where Y is a n-dimensional vector of the decision variables, U is the q-dimensional uncertain vector represented by interval numbers. b i I is the interval of the i-th constraint, U I is the interval of the uncertain vector, U i respresents the i-th uncertain variable. In order to convert the uncertain constraints, the interval order relation and interval possibility degree should be considered to compare interval numbers [40]. Based on them, the uncertain constraints can be transformed into deterministic constrains [6] (34) P ( g i I ( Y ) ⩽ b i I ) ⩾ λ i where λ i ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] , which is a predefined possibility. g i I ( Y ) is the interval value of the uncertain constraints. It can be solved by two optimization processes [40]. (35) g i - ( Y ) = min U g i ( Y , U ) , g i + ( Y ) = max U g i ( Y , U ) Through the above method, all the uncertain constraints can be transformed into deterministic constraints. Likewise, two optimization processes are used to get f - ( Y ) and f + ( Y ) (38) f - ( Y ) = min U f ( Y , U ) , f + ( Y ) = max U f ( Y , U ) In order to solve this deterministic objective function with subsequent algorithm, linear weighting [6] is used to further transform Eq. The results of transforming interval optimization into deterministic optimization can be expressed as: Objective function: Eq. (41); Constraints: Eq. (22), Eq. (28)–(30), Eqs. (42) and (43). The above deterministic optimization model is a typical nonlinear optimization problem. As an intelligent algorithm, Genetic Algorithm (GA) [41] is suitable for solving nonlinear deterministic problems. Hence, we choose GA to solve this problem. 5 Cases study 5.1 Cases design The system structure of the cases in this paper is shown in Fig. 1. The total simulation time is 24 h and the simulation step is 30 min. So Δ t is 0.5. The lower and upper limits of hot water temperature are 56 °C and 68 °C respectively. And the lower and upper limits of room temperature are 23 °C and 28 °C respectively. Parameters of WH, AC, CW, and KS are shown in Tables 1–3 . The P mustrun is shown in Fig. 3 . The electricity price is the time-of-use price in Ontario, Canada and its curve is shown in Fig. 4 [42], and set p sell , n = 0.8 p buy , n . The gas price is 9 cents/m3. The PV output curve is shown in Fig. 5 . The interval curves of hot water demand and ambient temperature are shown in Figs. 6 and 7 respectively. λ eCO 2 , λ eSO 2 and λ eNO X are 0.997 kg/kWh, 0.03 kg/kWh and 0.015 kg/kWh respectively. λ gCO 2 , λ gSO 2 and λ gNO X are 1.96 kg/m3, 1.5*10e-6 kg/m3 and 6∗10e-6 kg/m3 [36]. u 1 , u 2 and u 3 are 1.7 cents/kg, 9 cents/kg and 6 cents/kg [37,38]. α is set to 0.5, and β is 0.8. Users’ tolerance degree of hot water temperature and room temperature, σ 1 , σ 2 , σ 3 , σ 4 are set either 0.1 or 0, based on whether tolerance degree is considered or not. In order to study the impacts of interval optimization, tolerance degree and gas-electric multi-energy consumption on the operation cost and emission cost of HMES. Four cases are designed to compare and analyze. All the four cases include electricity, natural gas and PV energy. To make the description simple, we use UAIO to represent considering uncertainty of HMES (including hot water demand, hot water temperature, ambient temperature, room temperature and PV output) and dealing uncertainty with interval optimization. Similar to actual engineering application [25], when the uncertainty of HMES is ignored, the value of an uncertain variable can be represented by the midpoint of its interval. The specific settings of the four cases are as follows: Case 1: The based case, considering utility power, natural gas, PV, ignoring the uncertainty of HMES, taking no account of IDR, UAIO and tolerance degree. KS is set to consume natural gas only, and WH is set to consume electricity only. To maximize the users’ comfort level, WH and AC are set at the medium value in comfort temperature range, that, WH and AC respectively maintain 62 °C and 25.5 °C, while KS and CW work as needed. Case 2: Sharing the same settings with Case 1 besides IDR. This is, considering IDR ignoring the uncertainty of HMES, and taking no account of UAIO and tolerance degree. Case 3: Remaining the same settings with Case 2 besides the uncertainty. Interval optimization is applied to deal with the uncertainty of HMES. Hot water temperature maintains the interval [56 °C, 68 °C], and room temperature maintains in the interval [23 °C, 28 °C]. That is, considering IDR and UAIO, taking no account of tolerance degree. Case 4: Considering tolerance degree compared with Case 3 while other settings remain the same. In general, considering IDR, UAIO and tolerance degree all. The simulation is implemented in MATLAB R2018a with GA solver on a PC with Intel Core i5 3.30 GHz CPU and 8 GB RAM. The GA solver is supplied by and built within MATLAB R2018a. The solver handles the variables X = { X h , n , h = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 ; n = 1 , 2 , 3 … 48 } in order to minimize the objective function Eq. (41). The specific parameters of the GA solver are set as follows: population size equals to 100, crossover fraction equals to 0.8, migration fraction equals to 0.2, elite count equals to 5, maximum generation equals to 1000, stall generation limit equals to 200, and other parameters are default values of GA solver of MATLAB R2018a. 5.2 Results analysis The operation cost and emissions of harmful gases in four cases are shown in Table 4 . Moor R [34] proposed to use the midpoint of interval to compare interval numbers. Assuming a I = a - , a + , b I = b - , b + , it is said that a I is bigger than b I , if a - + a + 2 > b - + b + 2 . Medium values in Table 4 are the midpoints of the intervals calculated by the above method. Comparing the data of Case 1 with Case 2, all emissions and the operation cost of Case 2 are smaller than those of Case 1. Specifically, the operation cost of Case 2 is 11.6% lower than that of Case 1. In terms of the pollution cost, that of Case 2 is 14.77 cents lower than that of Case 1, accounting for 13.8% in percentage. And the total cost of Case 2 is reduced by 12.2% compared with Case 1. The daily reduction in the operation cost and pollution cost of Case 2 is attributed to IDR into HMES. It’s seen that the participation of IDR in HMES can significantly reduce emissions of harmful gases and the operation cost, which demonstrates the superiority of gas-electric equipment and IDR. Case 2 and Case 3 both consider the comprehensive utilization of natural gas and electricity. Comparing results of Case 2 with medium values of Case 3, it’s seen that emissions of CO 2 , SO 2 and NO X of Case 2 are smaller than those of Case 3. The operation cost and the total cost of Case 2 is slightly smaller than those of Case 3. Whereas, it is difficult to manifest that Case 2 is better than Case 3 through the data, for Case 2 doesn’t consider uncertainty of HMES. However, uncertainty is an objective fact. In real operation, PV output, hot water temperature, room temperature and hot water demand may deviate largely from the set point. Therefore, for scheduling results of Case 2, it is considerably hard to ensure that the operation effects on each device satisfy users’ comfort. Even if the system runs according to the scheduling results of Case 2, it is also hard to achieve the listed optimization effects in real systems. At the same time, according to its scheme, Case 2 may require the utility energy system to compensate for the deficiencies and balances of load scheduling, which will consume the precious reserve of the utility energy system. Case 3 fully considers uncertain factors and deal with the uncertainty by interval optimization. Ensuring the availability of optimization results in the ranges of uncertain parameters is an important feature of interval optimization. Meanwhile, the scheduling results of Case 3 can be accepted by users and consume almost no spares of the utility energy system. Hence, Case 3 is a relatively robust way. It means that in HMES optimization, the results have good performance economically and robustly when uncertainties are considered via interval optimization approach, compared with the optimization results ignoring uncertainties. In Table 4, comparing median values of Case 3 with Case 4, it’s seen that emissions and the operation cost of Case 4 are superior to those of Case 3. The daily reduction in the operation cost resulted from the tolerance degree is 13.7%. Adding the pollution cost, the total cost of Case 4 is reduced by 13.9% compared with Case 3. The reason is that Case 4 takes into account users’ tolerance degree, which allows hot water temperature and room temperature occasionally exceeding the given range in a small scale. Comparing with Case 3, Case 4 can further optimize the operation cost and emissions while ensuring the scheduling results accepted by users. On the whole, comparing with the based Case 1, the operation cost of Case 4 is reduced by 23%, and the total cost is reduced by 23.4%. In addition, the operation cost of Case 4 is 13% lower than that of Case 2, and the reduction of the total cost is 12.9%. These are because IDR and tolerance degree are taken into account. It means that IDR and tolerance degree have an accumulative effect on the system optimization. The interval curves of hot water temperature and room temperature in Case 3 are shown in Figs. 8 and 9 , and those of Case 4 are shown in Figs. 10 and 11 . As shown in Figs. 8 and 9, hot water temperature and room temperature are strictly controlled within the most suitable interval. At the same time, when hot water demand is high, such as at 7:00, 8:00, 19:00 and 20:00, the interval range of hot water temperature is also increasing. Moreover, hot water temperature is maintained at higher temperature at 10:00–16:00. It is because hot water demand and time-of-use electricity price are lower at these moments. It indicates that WH can store enough hot water at high temperature to satisfy the peak water demand. Room temperature is strictly controlled within the most suitable interval and maintained nearby the midpoint 25.5 °C. It’s seen that the proposed interval optimization method can ensure stability of the scheduling results for all possible scenarios. The scheduling results indicate that this strategy is robust to the uncertainties and provides users with the most suitable temperature interval under uncertain context. In Case 4, considering users’ tolerance degree of hot water temperature and room temperature, the interval of hot water temperature in the scheduling results is [54.77 °C, 69.45 °C], and the interval of room temperature in the scheduling results is [22.49 °C, 28.62 °C]. As shown in Fig. 10, hot water temperature breakes through the most suitable interval for five times at 7:30, 10:30, 12:30, 16:30 and 21:00. The temperatures are 55.23 °C, 55.52 °C, 55.45 °C, 69.02 °C and 55.12 °C respectively. Comparing with the most suitable interval [56 °C, 68 °C], hot water temperature over-limit does not exceed 1.02 °C as a whole. Although the total time over-limit is about 10.4%, the maximum over-limit temperature is only 1.5% larger than the upper limit of the most suitable interval, which is acceptable for users. As shown in Fig. 11, room temperature breaks through the most suitable interval for eight times at 4:00, 4:30, 6:30, 7:00, 9:00, 13:30, 16:00 and 17:30. The temperatures are 22.65 °C, 22.90 °C, 22.52 °C, 22.93 °C, 22.82 °C, 22.73 °C, 22.65 °C and 22.83 °C respectively. Comparing with the most suitable interval [23 °C, 28 °C], room temperature over-limit is less than 0.48 °C. As a whole, the total time over-limit is about 16.7%, but the minimum room temperature is 2.1% less than the low limit of the most suitable interval, which is acceptable for users. Fortunately, according to high cost and emissions, the majority of users prefer minimizing the total payment even if users’ comfort decreasing. It means that tolerance degree can obtain a scheduling scheme with acceptable comfort temperature intervals, and has an accumulative effect on the system optimization. Figs. 12 and 13 show the scheduling results of each load in Case 3 and Case 4 respectively. As shown in Figs. 12 and 13, WH and KS can only use electricity or gas alone during a scheduling step. In terms of the whole scheduling cycle, WH and KS switch energy forms between natural gas and electricity dynamically. Moreover, the cooking process is always continuous, and the running time is 3 h conforming to the setting time in Table 1. The total running step of CW is 6 the same as to 3 h, which conforms to the setting time in Table 1. Combined with time-of-use electricity price of shown in Fig. 4, CW always runs in the afternoon when electricity price is low. As shown in Figs. 12 and 13, electricity price is at a low level at 1:00–5:00 and 20:00–24:00, equipment involved scheduling uses electricity as much as possible, and WH and AC perform to store energy. At 6:00–9:00 and 17:00–19:00, electricity price is at a high level, gas-electric equipment switches from using electricity to using natural gas. At 10:00–16:00, the average of electricity price is at a middle level, the energy consumption of equipment is slightly complicated, and the energy consumption law is not obvious. But in all possible scenarios, the proposed method can provide accurate scheduling results. From Fig. 10, hot water temperature breaks through the most suitable interval for five times. Referring specifically to Fig. 13, WH is heating by using natural gas when electricity price is at a high level at 8:00. At 11:00 and 13:30, electricity price is at a middle level, and WH uses electricity to raise hot water temperature. Moreover, at 21:30, electricity price is at a low level, but hot water demand is large, and WH selects natural gas to heat. Room temperature breaks through the comfort interval for eight times. It is because that AC starts and stops intermittenly. It’s seen that tolerance degree in Case 4 provides flexibility in energy consumption, enabling users to better respond to electricity price. Furthermore, it can also avoid the loss caused by storing hot water and maintaining room temperature, thus comprehensively achieving the goal of reducing the operation cost and emissions of harmful gases. 6 Conclusion In this paper, we propose an interval optimization strategy based on IDR for HMES, which takes into account the dynamic switching between electrical energy and natural gas energy types of gas-electric equipment and combines it with users’ tolerance degree. The optimization objective of HMES is to reduce the total operating cost and harmful gases emissions. In our model, the uncertain parameters, which are modeled as interval numbers, include hot water demand, hot water temperature, ambient temperature, room temperature and PV output. Users’ tolerance degree of hot water temperature and room temperature is modeled as a system constraint. The interval optimization equation is transformed into deterministic equation by using interval order relation and interval possibility degree, and solved by GA algorithm. Simulation results indicate that the proposed method (considering IDR, tolerance degree and interval optimization) can significantly reduce the energy cost and emissions of HMES with gas-electric equipment up to 23.4% compared with conventional strategy (without IDR, tolerance degree and interval optimization). In addition, under the condition that interval optimization is adopted to deal with the system uncertainty, the effectiveness of IDR and tolerance degree on the system optimization is obtained respectively through simulation. Simulation results indicate that IDR and tolerance degree can effectively reduce the operating cost and emissions of electricity and natural gas dynamic switching system. At the same time, for this kind of system, considering IDR and tolerance can get a better optimization result than considering one of them alone. IDR and tolerance degree have an accumulative effect on minimizing operation cost and system emission cost. Moreover, similar to most systems with uncertainty, this system also gains higher robustness by applying interval optimization. It is a subject worthy of further study to integrate electrical storage devices into gas-electric equipment system. This may cover storage capacity optimization and system IDR strategy. However, how to avoid possible interferences caused by inappropriate storage capacity remains an open problem for related researches. In addition, this paper only contains TOU-based IDR, but actually, real-time pricing based and incentive-based IDR are also important ways for home energy management, and are worthy of being studied. coredata.dc:description: Under the background of the popularity of household gas-electric equipment, an interval optimization method considering the Integrated Demand Response (IDR) and tolerance degree is proposed to deal with the household load scheduling. The proposed method mainly tackles the dynamic switching of energy forms (natural gas and electricity) and uncertain variables in the system caused by household load and photovoltaic (PV). The thermostatically controllable loads contain gas-electric heater and air conditioning, and the interruptible loads contain gas-electric kitchen stove and clothes washer. An interval optimization model is formulated to optimize the operation cost and emissions of a household multi-energy system. The uncertain parameters are modeled as interval numbers, and the constraints are relaxed by tolerance degree. To solve the equation, the interval optimization model is transformed into a deterministic optimization model based on the interval order relation and interval possibility degree. Then, Genetic Algorithm is applied to solve the deterministic optimization model. Simulation results indicate that interval optimization is robust to the uncertainties and flexible to meet users’ demands. Both IDR and tolerance degree are able to optimize users’ energy cost, and the optimization results are accumulative. For a gas-electric equipment installed home, the proposed method can reduce expenditures by up to 23.4% compared with traditional method that do not consider IDR, tolerance degree and interval optimization.
coredata.dc:title: An interval optimization strategy of household multi-energy system considering tolerance degree and integrated demand response
